Issues.Title: Change static priority resolution to be same level as directive it belongs to
Issues.Body:
This change changes the priority order of static styling. 

Current priority:
```
(least priority)
- Static 
  - Component
  - Directives
  - Template
- Dynamic Binding
  - Component
    - Map/Interpolation
    - Property
  - Directives
    - Map/Interpolation
    - Property
  - Template
    - Map/Interpolation
    - Property
(highest priority)
```

The issue with the above priority is this use case:

```
<div style="color: red;" directive-which-sets-color-blue>
```
In the above case the directive will win and the resulting color will be `blue`. However a small change of adding interpolation to the example like so. (Style interpolation is coming in https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/34202)
```
<div style="color: red; width: {{exp}}px" directive-which-sets-color-blue>
```
Changes the priority from static binding to interpolated binding which means now the resulting color is `red`. It is very surprising that adding an unrelated interpolation and style can change the `color` which was not changed. To fix that we need to make sure that the static values are associated with priority of the source (directive or template) where they were declared. The new resulting priority is:


```
(least priority)
- Component
  - Static
  - Map/Interpolation
  - Property
- Directives
  - Static
  - Map/Interpolation
  - Property
- Template
  - Static
  - Map/Interpolation
  - Property
(highest priority)
```

Issues.Title: Clarify distinction between `deployUrl` and `baseUrl`
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

## Description

Issues.Title: Potential bug in the routing example stackblitz program
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description The example presented in https://angular.io/generated/live-examples/router/stackblitz.html (live example) does not exhibit the behaviour claimed in the documentation at https://angular.io/guide/router#query-parameters-and-fragments. Namely, this: > Now, you can click on the Admin button, which takes you to the Login page with the provided queryParamMap and fragment. After you click the login button, notice that you have been redirected to the Admin Dashboard page with the query parameters and fragment still intact in the address bar. The query parameter and the fragment both get lost when you are forwarded to the "admin" page by the login button. You can see that the "Admin" page displays `Null` both for `Session ID` and for `Token`, as they are also absent in the address bar. The cause seems to be the `navigateByUrl()` call in `auth/login/login.component.ts` at line 40. This is what the official doc says for this function referring to its `extras` parameter: > NavigationExtras | An object containing properties that modify the navigation strategy. The function ignores any properties in the¬†NavigationExtras¬†that would change the provided URL. So if you replace line 40 ``` this.router.navigateByUrl(redirect, navigationExtras); ``` with ``` this.router.navigate([this.authService.redirectUrl], navigationExtras); ``` the app behaviour is then consistent with the expected description in the angular write-up. While `navigate()` is normally doing a relative navigation, in the absence of a "start" (`relativeTo`) position it will do the absolute navigation, but without the adverse effect of `navigateByUrl()`. Maybe not the most optimal solution though But notice that if this solution is adopted, the `UrlTree` `redirect` variable is then not necessary Also the Angular Doc write‚Äìup has to be updated as well to whatever solution is adopted ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/generated/live-examples/router/stackblitz.html and the documentation at https://angular.io/guide/router#query-parameters-and-fragments ### Reproduction Steps** Navigate to https://angular.io/generated/live-examples/router/stackblitz.html, then to `Admin` tab and click the `Login` button. You will see both `Session ID` and `Token` being `None` ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** `Session ID` should be `123456789`, and `Token` should be `anchor`, and not `None` Otherwise how are they persistent? ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Add support for *.html via the raw-loader to the webpack.config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular:karma
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature Request: Add support for *.html via the raw-loader to the webpack.config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular:karma

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [x] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

#### Background
I am working on a legacy AngularJS application. Migrating the entire code base to Angular is not technically viable at this point in time. As a solution I have dual bootstrap the AngularJS application with the Angular ngUpgrade module so the application can be migrated over time. 

At this initial stage of the project I am using the existing webpack.config to build the app. My webpack.config handles the transpilation of the Typescript and Angular by way of the ts-loader. Everything compiles and loads and I can proceed with Angular while maintaining existing AngularJS code.

At present I do not get the full benefit of the Angular CLI, but will in future as more legacy code is migrated and the CLI is used to it's full capability. At present thou it should be possible for me to use the lint and test commands against all new Angular code even thou it isn't being built or served by the Angular CLI.

#### The actual feature request

The issue comes into play when I attempt to use `ng test` to test new Angular components. `ng test`, or more specifically the angular-devkit/build-angular:karma plugin. Out of the box it doesn't support native ES6 imports for html files within Angular components. Running `ng test` on files written like:

```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';

import template from './my-component.component.html';

@Component({
    selector: 'my-component',
    template
})
public class MyComponent {
```

results in:

```
ERROR in ./src/app/my-component/my-component.component.html 1:0
Module parse failed: Unexpected token (1:0)
You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type, currently no loaders are configured to process this file. See https://webpack.js.org/concepts#loaders
```

I cannot use the Angular CLI to build at this time, so using templateUrl is out as it results distribution  making requests to the server for the templates. I assume this is because I don't have a full AOT configuration provided natively by the Angular CLI.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like the `\.html$` files to be handled by the webpack config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular/plugins/karma`. This can be achieved simply by adding (or something similar):

```
webpackConfig.module.rules.push({
    test: /\.html$/,
    use: [{loader: 'raw-loader'}]
});
```

I was thinking `raw-loader` only because you already have it as a dependency; otherwise `html-loader` would also work with the additional configuration option for `caseSensitive: true`. It's a little insane that the plugin supports imports of every other typical file type but not html:

```
[
  {
    test: /\.(eot|svg|cur|jpg|png|webp|gif|otf|ttf|woff|woff2|ani)$/,
    loader: 'file-loader',
    options: { name: '[name].[ext]' }
  },
  {
    test: /[\/\\]@angular[\/\\]core[\/\\].+\.js$/,
    parser: { system: true }
  },
  { test: /[\/\\]hot[\/\\]emitter\.js$/, parser: { node: [Object] } },
  {
    test: /[\/\\]webpack-dev-server[\/\\]client[\/\\]utils[\/\\]createSocketUrl\.js$/,
    parser: { node: [Object] }
  },
  { test: /\.js$/, exclude: /(ngfactory|ngstyle)\.js$/ },
  {
    test: /\.js$/,
    exclude: /(ngfactory|ngstyle)\.js$/,
    enforce: 'pre'
  },
  { exclude: [], test: /\.css$/, use: [ [Object], [Object] ] },
  {
    exclude: [],
    test: /\.scss$|\.sass$/,
    use: [ [Object], [Object], [Object] ]
  },
  {
    exclude: [],
    test: /\.less$/,
    use: [ [Object], [Object], [Object] ]
  },
  {
    exclude: [],
    test: /\.styl$/,
    use: [ [Object], [Object], [Object] ]
  },
  {
    test: /\.tsx?$/,
    loader: '/<omitted>/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js'
  },
  {
    test: /\.(jsx?|tsx?)$/,
    loader: '/<omitted>/node_modules/coverage-istanbul-loader/lib/index.js',
    options: { esModules: true },
    enforce: 'post',
    exclude: [ /\.(e2e|spec)\.ts$/, /node_modules/ ],
    include: '<omitted>'
  }
]
```

This shouldn't impact the usage of Angular's template or templateUrls because they aren't native requires or imports; just strings and webpack will ignore them.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I have tried several work arounds including attempting to preprocess the files like in AngularJS and replace templateUrl with the embedded html string. Looked into other angular tooling that will build angular in my existing webpack config; but all these solutions feel dirty.

My least offensive workaround for my issue is to publish my own hacked version of the angular-devkit/build-angular library that applies the above mentioned patch so I can process test files in a way I expect until which time I can move to a world strictly with the angular-cli.

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/testing): TestElement sendKeys method should not throw if no keys have been specified
Issues.Body:
Previously, calling `sendKeys` without any keys resulted in an error
being thrown. This is because the first element of the passed arguments
to `sendKeys` has been considered always truthy. This assumption is
wrong since arbitrary amount of arguments can be passed due to the
spread parameter.

Also, calling `sendKeys` without any keys should not result in the
element being focused. Pressing no keys/entering no text, does require
the element to be focused.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/testing): TestElement sendKeys method should not throw if no keys have been specified" (#18271)

Issues.Title: mat-slide-toggle fails to toggle upon mouse click when text is selected elsewhere on form
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Using Chrome, see the following StackBlitz:   https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-1ztoyy

Steps to reproduce:
1. Upon page load, note that the mat-slide-toggle properly responds to click events by toggling itself.
2. After 5 seconds, the page is programmatically selecting text in a nearby textbox. (You can also reproduce the issue by manually selecting the text.)
3. Without clicking anywhere else, try the mat-slide-toggle again, and note that it no longer toggles upon click. (The ripple effect does appear, indicating that it knows it has been clicked. Interestingly, double-click does work.)
4. Clicking elsewhere on the form restores the expected behavior (presumably because this causes the selected text to be de-selected). 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The mat-slide-toggle control should toggle its state when clicked.

#### Actual Behavior

After selecting text in another field, the mat-slide-toggle no longer toggles its state when clicked.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.0.0-rc.9    (This does not appear to be an issue in Angular 8 / Material 8)
- CDK/Material: Material 9.0.0-rc.8
- Browser(s):  Chrome 79.0.3945.130 (64-bit) (issue does not appear to occur in Edge or Firefox)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows 10 x64
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-slide-toggle fails to toggle upon mouse click when text is selected elsewhere on form" (#18269)

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-form-field): ensure validity styling is not reset by foundation
Issues.Body:
Currently, whenever the abstract form-field control turns invalid, the
text-field foundation does not know about the validity change. Since it
refreshes the validity upon focus/blur, it could end up accidentally
removing the invalid class. We fix this, by ensuring that the foundation
shares the validity state with the one from the form-field control.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental/mdc-form-field): ensure validity styling is not reset by foundation" (#18266)

Issues.Title: mat-datepicker select "in" and "out" type for two-way binding (e.g. ISO date string)
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Please provide a way to deal with ISO date strings in two-way binding (e.g. `ngModel`).

Probably it does not end with the ISO date string as a possible type. Let's say another example is to use `google.protobuf.Timestamp` from protobuf as input and output for the model.

It might be that I'm repeating another issue here, however I did not succeed finding one.

#### Use Case

I want to pass string as input for datepicker and receive string as output. That's normally a quite expected behavior from a form input and it is definitely not in place; a `Moment` instance is replacing my input, although it was of type `string` (I use moment date adapter)

Currently I need to perform ugly patching like `(ngModelChange)="contact.birthDate = $event.toISOString()"`

```html
<mat-form-field>
    <mat-label>{{ 'entity:ContactPerson/property:birthDate/name' | translate }}</mat-label>
    <input matInput [matDatepicker]="picker" #birthDateModel="ngModel" [(ngModel)]="contact.birthDate" name="contact.birthDate" (ngModelChange)="contact.birthDate = $event.toISOString()">
    <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
    <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
  </mat-form-field>
```

[Another example on SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55657747/how-to-two-way-bind-angular-material-datepicker-to-a-string-property)

If there is another cleaner way to achieve the string in -> string out (or any custom type) behavior, please guide me.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-datepicker select "in" and "out" type for two-way binding (e.g. ISO date string)" (#18253)

Issues.Title: Entry point configuration check should run against release package
Issues.Body:
The entry-point configuration CI check should run against the release package, and not run simply against the `config.bzl` file. The reason for this is that we don't need to generate manifests and pass data through `.bzl` files to the JS script. 

Also configuring does not always mean that the entry point is actually released. We could incorporate this into the release validation scripts that already run on CI anyway.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Entry point configuration check should run against release package" (#18250)
